results.name: Triangle T(n,k) = (n/k)*binomial(n-k-1, k-1) read by rows.
comment: Triangle A034807 (coefficients of Lucas polynomials) with the first column omitted. - _Philippe Deléham_, Mar 17 2013
T(n,k) is the number of ways to select k knights from a round table of n knights, no two adjacent. - _Bert Seghers_, Mar 02 2014
reference: J. Riordan, An Introduction to Combinatorial Analysis, Wiley, 1958, pp. 199
link: G. C. Greubel, Rows n = 2..100 of triangle, flattened
example: The table starts in row n=2, column k=1 as:
mathematica: Table[(n/k)*Binomial[n-k-1, k-1], {n,2,20}, {k,1,Floor[n/2]}]//Flatten (* modified by _G. C. Greubel_, Apr 25 2019 *)
program: (MAGMA) [[n*Binomial(n-k-1,k-1)/k: k in [1..Floor(n/2)]]: n in [2..20]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Apr 25 2019
(Sage) [[n*binomial(n-k-1,k-1)/k for k in (1..floor(n/2))] for n in (2..20)] # _G. C. Greubel_, Apr 25 2019
